nodes.text: Machine learning classifiers (SVM, KNN, Random Forest) can be used to detect lung cancer from CT images for early-stage diagnosis
Dataset: 500 CT images from LIDC-IDRI were used, with additional small validation samples from AHRC and AIMS; images downsampled from 512x512x3 to 256x and split 70% train / 30% test
Preprocessing: image enhancement and denoising applied (CLAHE, Wiener, adaptive Gaussian, Gaussian and Gabor filters); segmentation used thresholding and marker-controlled watershed

Model training: three classifiers implemented in MATLAB - KNN (Euclidean distance), SVM (maximal margin hyperplane), Random Forest (ensemble of decision trees with bootstrap and feature randomness); 5-fold cross-validation used
Clinical validation: small external sample set annotated and reviewed by an AIMS radiologist to validate computational results
Feature extraction and labeling: images labeled as abnormal (NSCLC various stages) or normal; features extracted after preprocessing for classifier input
Training/testing protocol: 70% of data used to train models, 30% held out for evaluation; performance measured with accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, TPR, FPR, AUC, FAR, FRR
SVM, KNN, and Random Forest classifiers were compared to identify the best-performing algorithm for lung cancer classification
Result: SVM achieved average accuracy 95.06% (5-fold CV), average precision 0.95, average recall 0.99 and per-fold accuracies shown; ROC-AUC >0.99 reported per class
Result: KNN achieved average accuracy 86.89% (5-fold CV) with average precision 0.84 and recall 0.98
Result: Random Forest achieved average accuracy 81.96% (5-fold CV) with average precision 0.78 and recall 0.98
Claim: SVM outperforms KNN and Random Forest on this dataset because it handles complex decision boundaries and high-dimensional features better, yielding superior generalization

Conclusion: The proposed image-processing pipeline plus SVM classifier can detect lung cancer from CT images with high accuracy (95.06%) and may assist early diagnosis, potentially improving patient outcomes

Limitation and future work: study used a relatively small dataset (500 images) and limited external validation; future work will expand dataset diversity, stages, and demographics to improve performance and reliability
